fields.description:
Dynamic Lookups (recommended method) - Applications should follow the guidance found in Internet Engineering Task Force Request for Comments 2782 (http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2782.txt): A DNS RR for specifying the location of services (DNS SRV). The RFC outlines how a client can query for services (LDAP for domain or GC for forest) using the Domain Name System (DNS). Also, application code can use serverless binding techniques such as LDAP://RootDSE or GC://<forestname>. Serverless binding techniques allow the application code to find any available domain controller with preference given to domain controllers in the same Site (see next section "Site Aware").

NOTE: When using the serverless binding technique, please note that LDAP://nam.nsroot.net is not the
same as LDAP://DC=nam,DC=nsroot,DC=net.
If the application uses LDAP://nam.nsroot.net, a domain controller is located based on the DNS
round robin function of offering all the registered 'A' (Host) records for the domain in a random order. The impact of this method is that DNS will offer 'A' records in a random order, thus the application could receive an IP address of a remote domain controller. In addition, the records returned in response to the 'A' query may not represent domain controllers that are online or available for use by the application as DNS is not aware of the status of the domain controller or the application services it provides.
If the application uses LDAP://DC=nam,DC=nsroot,DC=net, it is using the serverless binding
technique and relying upon the Directory Service DCLocator function. The DCLocator function(http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms675900(VS.85).aspx\) is
AD Site Aware and will select a domain controller closest to the server and will also ensure that the domain controller is responsive.
fields.summary: Please add the ability to use dynamic lookups instead of DNS name lookups to connect to Active Directory on Crowd / Embedded Crowd

The context here is to be able to reset email for SSO use with a plugin (e.g. Mini Orange Inc)

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

As a solution for CWD-5477 we've extended */admin/latest/server-info* to include following new information:
 * base URL
 * versions
 * deployment type
 * server time

 Here's an example of response from this endpoint in *Crowd 4.1*:
{code:java}
{
  "version": "4.1.0",
  "deploymentTitle": "CROWD",
  "buildNumber": 1529,
  "buildDate": "2020-06-19",
  "baseUrl": "https://mycrowd.com",
  "versions": [
    "4",
    "1",
    "0"
  ],
  "deploymentType": "Server",
  "serverTime": "2020-06-22T13:48:30.818+0000"
}
{code}
With those changes Crowd’s *server-info* endpoint returns an identical set of data to Jira’s server info endpoint. However there may be more Crowd specific data that would be of value to the endpoint’s consumers. An example of such data is the list from the original ticket (CWD-5477), which included data from the following pages:
 * [http://localhost:8095/crowd/console/secure/admin/general.action]
 * [http://localhost:8095/crowd/console/secure/admin/licensing.action]
 * [http://localhost:8095/crowd/console/secure/admin/systeminfo.action]
 * [http://localhost:8095/crowd/plugins/servlet/cluster-monitoring]
fields.summary: Add more data to server-info REST endpoint

fields.description: At the moment, Crowd only supports displaying inactive users against the particular applications, it would make sense to have strategic view where we could see the inactive users across all applications.
fields.summary: Centralized license visibility should have strategic view to display users that are inactive across all applications connected to the Crowd.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Crowd Passwrd History Doesn't Work Correctly
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Crowd does not behave correctly when changing a password based on the stored password history count(13 was set for this case). The Password History Count is not used as the basis for the assessment when a user tries to use his initial password again after first change.

Here is a sample process:

1. Create a new user in crowd and enter a valid, new 15-digit pw as the initial password (Start#12345678!)
-> OK
2. Change the user's password in crowd with the same pw from point 1 (Start#12345678!)
-> does not work, which is OK
3. Change the user's password in the crowd with another valid pw (Start#12345678w)
-> OK
4. Change password again with the identical pw from point 1 (Start#12345678!)
-> password can be changed, which is NOT OK

h3. Expected Results

Crowd should not allow to use an old password based on history count.
h3. Actual Results

User is able to set old password.
h3. Workaround


 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Crowd Password History Doesn't Work Correctly

fields.description:
I do not know, where to put this request so I put it here.

I would like to add apps on the marketplace to my personal favorite list, when I am logged in. To find interesting Apps easily again, next time I log in.
fields.summary: Favorites on Atlassian Marketplace

'Last synchronised' date/time for a remote directory on User Directories page does not obey current user time zone nor date formatting

It should display the date and time using current user timezone and date formatting
h3. Actual Results

It displays the time in the server's timezone and date format does not obey user preferences

fields.summary: 'Last synchronised' date/time for a remote directory on User Directories page does not obey current user time zone nor date formatting

fields.description:
As a Crowd administrator, it would be useful to have a flag that could globally disable the ability to change passwords, especially when an external directory is in use and is the source of truth. 

Or, have a flag that could disable password changes per directory.
fields.summary: Create global configuration option to disable password changes

fields.description:
h3. Summary
+As a+ System Admin
+I want to+ have database credentials on local nodes
+So that I can+ have a better handling of the different instances on my environment, such as Production versus Staging versus Business Continuity, etc

h3. Problem Definition

Customer has different environments with Crowd Data Center clusters for each scenario, such as Production, Business Continuity, Staging, Development, QA, etc.
To refresh these environments data from production storage (shared folder) is copied to those environments, so is also copied the {{crowd.cfg.xml}} file, which contain the database credentials. Those need to be updated on each refresh, to point to the correct database instance

In a situation, for example, when Production cluster is totally down and they want to activate Business Continuity one, they need to make sure that the database connection information and credentials are the correct ones. Whether, if that was local in each node, they could have that correctly setup during server build.

h3. Suggested Solution
Have Crowd handle the {{crowd.cfg.xml}} file the same way Confluence does with {{confluence.cfg.xml}} or Jira with the {{dbconfig.xml}} one. Or let it be configurable.
 
h3. Workaround 
Customer currently have scripts on crontab to handle that.
fields.summary: Allow crowd.cfg.xml files to be local in each DC node instead of on shared folder

fields.description:
h3. Problem

As per exiting functionally granting Crowd user rights will give your users the power to update their own profiles and passwords and view their authorization details. 

Customers are looking for an option in the Crowd which they can configured so users can manage their password only but not their profile details (Name and Email).
h3. Suggested Solution

There should be an option for admin to disable editing in the user profile section.

Modify user permission locks both account details and password management.
h3. Why This Is Important

_This will restrict the user to change there Name & Email._ 
h3. Workaround

_(Add a workaround, if available)_
fields.summary: Option for the administrator to restrict the user to edit their profile

fields.description:
When we do a non-paged search, it would seem that LDAP returns a page of results and we just take the first one, and assume that there are no more which causes no delay or slowness in authentication.

When we do paged search we first try to parse the whole results page, thus following referrals even though we just need single result which causes a delay or slowness in authentication. This is not ideal or optimal.

If possible could the respective LDAP class be updated to better handle this referral logic to resolve the potential slowness problems that may be presented and be better optimized.
fields.summary: Update the LDAP paging search functionality to resolve potential authentication slowness

fields.description: If a user's attributes or data is updated by a Crowd admin, please include these events within the audit log.
fields.summary: Enhance Audit logs to record changes made to user attributes

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
For example, when a REST API call is made to Atlassian application (Confluence, Jira, BB), it'll return a token. In possession of this token, a user can use it in a browser and access Crowd's applications via Web UI.

If I have a central authentication server in my infrastructure (which enables 2FA, for example), that will handle requests made to my applications (Crowd included), then having this SSO token allowing UI access due to a REST call will bypass my 2FA auth app, which is not desirable.
fields.summary: As an admin, I wish to avoid Atlassian Application from sending SSO tokens in Basic Auth requests

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The order of the values returned from the following REST call is inconsistent. 
{code:java}
 /rest/usermanagement/1/group/user/direct  {code}
This is the case with the following conditions:
 * start-indext=0
 * max-results=10 
 * One or more of the results include an upper case letter. 

Steps to Reproduce
 # In Crowd ensure a group exists that includes few users. Ensure that an upper case username is present. 
 # Ensure that the group belongs to a directory that is configured to operate with an Application.
 # Using Postman or Curl run the following REST call
{code:java}
/rest/usermanagement/1/group/user/direct?groupname=confluence-users&start-index=0&max-results=2{code}

h3. Expected Results

When the result of the REST call does not include an upper case username, the results are ordered alphabetically.
{code:java}
/rest/usermanagement/1/group/user/direct?groupname=confluence-users&start-index=0&max-results=2 {code}
{code:java}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<users expand="user">
    <user name="admin">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=admin" rel="self"/>
    </user>
    <user name="confluence_user1">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=confluence_user1" rel="self"/>
    </user>
</users>{code}
When the result of the REST call  include an upper case username, the results should also be ordered the same way as it is ordered above. 
{code:java}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<users expand="user">
    
    <user name="admin">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=admin" rel="self"/>
    </user>
    <user name="confluence_user1">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=confluence_user1" rel="self"/>
    </user>
<user name="Faridi">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=Faridi" rel="self"/>
    </user>
    <user name="test">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=test" rel="self"/>
    </user>
    <user name="test12345">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=test12345" rel="self"/>
    </user>
</users>
{code}
h3. Actual Results

When the result of the REST call  include an upper case username, the results should also be ordered the same way as it is ordered above. 
{code:java}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<users expand="user">
    <user name="Faridi">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=Faridi" rel="self"/>
    </user>
    <user name="admin">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=admin" rel="self"/>
    </user>
    <user name="confluence_user1">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=confluence_user1" rel="self"/>
    </user>
    <user name="test">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=test" rel="self"/>
    </user>
    <user name="test12345">
        <link href="http://localhost:8095/tccrowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=test12345" rel="self"/>
    </user>
</users>
{code}
h3. Workaround

At the moment there is no known workaround
fields.summary: REST call returns values with inconsistent order

Currently, the audit logs tab presents only old and new values without focusing on sub-characters that actually have been changed. Where values could be potentially very long:

!image-2020-05-13-11-36-03-062.png|width=842,height=265!

The suggestion is about introduction a tool that will allow the system show the difference, so that admin will not need to review word for word on its own.

fields.description:
There are two artifacts in Atlassian public Maven repository(com.atlassian.crowd:crowd-integration-client-rest:4.0.0 and com.atlassian.crowd:crowd-api:4.0.0) that are used to provide a Crowd Rest Client to various applications.

In Java 11, JAXB has been removed from the base JDK. However, the Crowd Rest Client still requires that library (and potentially other transitive dependencies) but the Maven artifact does not declare them, leading to errors when the client requires it.

Atlassian artifact:
com.atlassian.crowd:crowd-integration-client:4.0.0

Missing dependencies:
javax.xml.bind:jaxb-api:2.3.1
org.glassfish.jaxb:jaxb-runtime:2.3.1
fields.summary: Missing dependencies in Maven for Crowd 4.0/Java 11

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Adding a logging package to "Logging and Profiling" may or may not show the added package but it will still take effect. If it shows after adding and you navigate away from the page and back, the package will disappear but will remain in effect.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to Logging and Profiling
 # Add {{com.mchange.v2.c3p0}} and set to DEBUG

h3. Expected Results

You will see {{com.mchange.v2.c3p0}} in the list of logging packages and be able to navigate away from the screen, come back and still see it.
h3. Actual Results

The {{com.mchange.v2.c3p0}} sometimes visually shows up after adding, sometimes not but the change seems to have still taken effect.

If it shows up in the list and you navigate to a different page and return to Logging and Profiling, the added package will disappear but the intended DEBUG logging will remain in effect until you click "Revert to Default"
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.

Click "Revert to Default" to remove the added package which cannot be seen.
fields.summary: Adding a logging package to "Logging and Profiling" may not show the package after adding but it does still take effect

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When an application is authenticating via SSO and authentication fails, Crowd does not provide any status or signal back to the application saying that the login attempt failed.

The lack of this information prevents the DC Advanced Auditing feature from recording an event for a "failed authentication".

Because Crowd does not record failed authentications in its Audit feature, there is no alternative to check this information via the product UI
fields.summary: When an application is authenticating via SSO, provide a "failure status" if the login fails

fields.description:
At the moment, the following algorithms are available when creating an Internal Directory:
* ATLASSIAN-SECURITY (which is PBKDF2 based)
* BECRYPT
* DES
* MD5
* SHA
* SSHA

Please add support for more hashing algorithms such as Argon2
fields.summary: Add support for the Argon2 hashing algorithm in Crowd

fields.description:
Currently, while using AD LDS with the AD Connector in Atlassian Crowd versions v3.6.0 and above, syncing will fail when Crowd attempts to fetch the AD server _InvocationId_. This is due to AD LDS presenting a different schema than what the AD Connector is expecting.

The current workaround is to use either use Atlassian Crowd v3.5.1 (or prior) or use the generic connector to complete the sync (however this doesn't support incremental sync like with the AD Connector).

Official request to support AD LDS in the AD Connector for future versions beyond 3.5.1
fields.summary: Support AD LDS using the AD Connector in future versions of Crowd

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Crowd implementation of SAL's {{LicenseHandler.getAllSupportEntitlementNumbers}} throws NPE when {{CrowdLicense.getSupportEntitlementNumber()}} returns {{null}}.

Server Platform team detected this in integration tests for Analytics Plugin. We run Crowd with {{maven-amps-plugin}}, the license on such instance has a {{null}} {{supportEntitlementNumber}} 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
{code}
git clone git@bitbucket.org:atlassian/atlassian-analytics.git
cd atlassian-analytics
git checkout 5.6.x_stable
mvn clean verify -DtestGroups=crowd-integration -Dcrowd.test.version=4.0.0
{code}
 
h3. Expected Results
Tests will pass

h3. Actual Results
Tests fail, wiring errors in Crowd log

h3. Workaround
Change Crowd license to one that contains SEN.
fields.summary: NPE in CrowdLicenseHandler.getAllSupportEntitlementNumbers

fields.summary: Custom Directory - Ability to

It would be beneficial to have a way to kill/stop/pause the synchronization job.

fields.description:
h4. Summary
When a group admin trying to add users into a group, they will need to search for the user beforehand.

h4. Problem Statement
When it comes to situation where users share the same full name, it will not be easy for a group admin to distinguish between them. For example, I can two users with the full name "cc cc" in my Crowd server:
 !Screenshot 2020-04-15 at 2.59.07 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Suggestion
The suggestion should also include usernames that are unique and easily distinguishable.
fields.summary: The search suggestion for "Group Administration" should return username instead of full name

fields.description:
h4. Summary
With the recently shipped "Group Administration" feature, a group admin can now manage groups by adding or removing users from a group that they're administering.

h4. Problem Statement
However, the feature is currently limited to only users within the group. The group admin would not be able to see if there's a nested group within the group they're administering.

h4. Suggestion
As of now, only the Crowd System Administrator has that visibility. It would be useful for a group admin to have that visibility to manage the group better.
fields.summary: As a group administrator, I'd like to manage groups within the group I administer

fields.description:
At the moment, you can only view a users Group memberships from a directory centric view. This also only shows direct membership, not the results of any group nesting (if enabled).

If a Crowd Application maps to multiple directories, and there's cross-directory nesting configured then what you can see in Crowd can be wildly different to what results in the application. 

eg:
 # Directory 1
 ## User
 ### [first.last@domain.com|mailto:first.last@domain.com]
 ## Groups
 ### Group 10
 #### Group 11A
 #### Group 11B

 ##### first.last@domain.com
 # Directory 2
 ## Groups
 ### Group 1
 #### Group 10

 

If an application is only mapped to Directory 1, then [first.last@domain.com|mailto:first.last@domain.com]  will be a direct member of Group 11B and nested in Group 10.

If an application is mapped to Directory 1 and Directory 2, then the [first.last@domain.com|mailto:first.last@domain.com] will also be a nested member of Group 1

 

Suggestions:
 # On the Application > $appName > Users tab - show the group hierarchy a user would have according to the Application view (at the moment, the only way we can see the Group 1 net result is to go in to Jira/Conf/etc (whatever the linked application is) and see the groups there
 # On the Directory > $directory > $user > Groups tab - show a summary of all groups for that directory (nested and direct), not just direct. Also indicate whether the current user is a member of that group via direct, nested or both

 

This type of information being exposed natively in Crowd would be a significant time saver as we work to maximize the value of our groups to simplify the permissions on our platform. While we can see the results in each application, it's extra context switching when we then need to be back in Crowd to add/remove the users
fields.summary: Provide a method in Crowd of showing a users group memberships as the Application would see them

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
# If an application is added into Crowd via the SOAP API, and the authenticateApplication with different casing will store tokens with the case specified in SOAP request, and not Crowd application. 
# For example if the application name is mytestapp, then SOAP requests below will store mytestapp, and myTestApp tokens in the crowd database.
# This causes the Application Sessions page in Crowd to not load.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add the application below via SOAP. or use Spring Security following the steps [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/integrating-crowd-with-spring-security-174752019.html]
** {code:java}
<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:urn="urn:SecurityServer" xmlns:aut="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">
   <soapenv:Header/>
   <soapenv:Body>
      <urn:authenticateApplication>
         <urn:in0>
            <!--Optional:-->
            <aut:credential>
               <!--Optional:-->
               <aut:credential>mytestapp</aut:credential>
               <!--Optional:-->
            </aut:credential>
            <!--Optional:-->
            <aut:name>mytestApp</aut:name>
            <!--Optional:-->
            <aut:validationFactors>             
            </aut:validationFactors>
         </urn:in0>
      </urn:authenticateApplication>
   </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>{code}
** {code:java}<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:urn="urn:SecurityServer" xmlns:aut="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">
   <soapenv:Header/>
   <soapenv:Body>
      <urn:authenticateApplication>
         <urn:in0>
            <!--Optional:-->
            <aut:credential>
               <!--Optional:-->
               <aut:credential>myTestApp</aut:credential>
               <!--Optional:-->
            </aut:credential>
            <!--Optional:-->
            <aut:name>mytestApp</aut:name>
            <!--Optional:-->
            <aut:validationFactors>        
            </aut:validationFactors>
         </urn:in0>
      </urn:authenticateApplication>
   </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>
{code}

h3. Expected Results
# A single token is created in the the crowd database.

h3. Actual Results
# Two tokens a present, one with the expected camel case, and another with the case specified in the config above.
# The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
2020-03-12 13:25:17,100 http-nio-8095-exec-18 ERROR [common.error.jersey.ThrowableExceptionMapper] Uncaught exception thrown by REST service: null
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.crowd.plugin.rest.entity.admin.ApplicationSessionsSearchResultEntity.fromToken(ApplicationSessionsSearchResultEntity.java:55)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.plugin.rest.service.controller.admin.SessionsAdminController.lambda$parseFetchedApplicationTokens$1(SessionsAdminController.java:115)
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
# Use [camel case|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camel_case] for tokens.
fields.summary: Executing SOAP authenticateApplication or Spring Security with different casing will store tokens with the case specified in SOAP request, and not Crowd application.

fields.description:
h3. Description
Crowd is able to import users directly from other Atlassian product's SQL database. Problem
is, it only imports 'local' users (Atlassian product's internal Crowd directory). However, the AD user's local group membership is not imported.

h3. Suggestion
Enable Crowd to import user-group mapping from Atlassian product's SQL database
regardless of the back end directory type; with a user interface that allows the administrator to
select 'source' and 'destination' directories provided there are multiple source and destination
directories.
fields.summary: Ability to import external directory users and groups into Crowd with native SQL importer

API does not have feature to set a value for external_id for users.
fields.summary: When using API, I want to set the external_id for users

fields.description:
Using Crowd Datacenter we can enable user license visibility management to find users who haven't logged on for 1/3/6 months on a given linked application.

The only action provided is 'export to CSV' which leaves the action still with us to be customised per application.

Using that csv-list, we can perform the following actions for each user:
{code:java}
i=user.name@example.com

curl -u "user:pass" -X DELETE "https://crowd.internal.com/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user/group/direct?username=${i}&groupname=confluence-users"
curl -u "user:pass" -X DELETE "https://crowd.internal.com/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user/attribute?username=${i}&attributename=autoGroupsAdded"
curl -u "user:pass" -X DELETE "https://crowd.internal.com/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user/attribute?username=${i}&attributename=invalidPasswordAttempts"{code}

It would be nice to have an action button presented to disable in a single click/button/bulk.
fields.summary: Ability to disable users from the "Central license management" page

fields.description: For users offen ignore some important information in the password forgotten email, I want to highlight these keywords or sentences in the template, hope I can use html tags to change the font color and size.
fields.summary: Allow using html tags in email template

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Currently, when admin try to create a new group and add the user to the group, the admin will need to create it in each user directory and add the user to the group created for that user directory. This is difficult for admin to manage the group membership as it require to repeat the steps of creating the group in each user directory.

Also, it could cause confusion to non-technical admin when trying to add user to a group where the group have not created in the user directory or the admin is not sure which group to select from the Group pages in Crowd as it is showing multiple group name with same name. This leads to the following:
* user groups need to be added to each active directory instance from which we expect
members to authenticate from, effectively multiplying the administrative work with the
number of directories.
Example: jira-users group need to be added to london.company.com ,
newyorg.company.com , tokyio.company.com
* delegated group admins need to be added as admin to all instances of example
'jira-users' group. Delegated Admins will see multiple user groups with the same
name, quite confusing to non-technical personnel.
* delegated group admins need to look for a given user in each and every directory,
again, multiplying the workload of user / group administration

h3. Suggestion
* have a new type of Crowd directory that allows to use delegated authentication
directories, and also allows user auto-creation on successful authentication
* Groups and memberships would be maintained only in this directory; delegated
authentication backends would not be queried nor updated for group information
* allowed authentication directories, their precedence and automatic group
membership could be configured for each Application just like now. Example: Jira
Application:
*# Crowd internal directory with delegated authentication (this is used to
determine group membership)
*# london.company.com delegated authentication only; with auto-group of
'jira-users'
*# tokyo.company.com delegated authentication only; with auto-group of
'jira-users' and 'jira-admins'
*# newyork.company.com delegated authentication only; with no automatic
group assignment
fields.summary: Ease the methond of adding user to a group accross multiple user directory.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary:

On Crowd, the forgotten login page should be accessible for logged in user,. which is no longer reachable post implementation of the betterSSO.
 So the forgotten password flow was rewritten during implementation of betterSSO:
 [https://bulldog.internal.atlassian.com/browse/KRAK-995]
 [https://bulldog.internal.atlassian.com/browse/KRAK-1001]

Here is the PR that removes forgotten login action:
 [https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/CWD/repos/crowd/pull-requests/1145/diff#components/crowd-web-app/src/main/webapp/console/forgottenlogindetails.jsp]

Per the recent implementation: Forgotten password page is now part of the login page which will redirect you to home screen if it detects that you have active session with Crowd.
 In customer's words - _*This isn't intuitive and continues to confuse our user base and would like the older method to be re-instated*_.

 

Expected Results

When the user is logged in and clicks on [#https://<Crowd FQDN/IP>/crowd/console/secure/console.action#/forgot-password|#/forgot-password] it should take the user to the forgotten password page.
h3. Actual Results

When the user is logged in and clicks on [#https://<Crowd FQDN/IP>/crowd/console/secure/console.action#/forgot-password|#/forgot-password]
 A new tab opens and one can see the URL as above however it shows the '*Welcome to the Crowd administration console*' page.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: With an Active User Session, Forgotten Password Link should redirect to page to reset the password options

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
There is a limitation for Crowd's [Directory Importer|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/importing-users-from-one-crowd-directory-into-another-128287098.html] where the _Password Encryption_ method must be the same in both directories.
This means that importing user from External Directories (Connector/Delegated) into Crowd's Internal Directory will not be possible and need to rely on the [CSV Importer|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/importing-users-from-csv-files-64454760.html] that requires further database access.

h3. Suggested Solution
As Crowd has a CSV Import feature, it would be good to also have *CSV Export* feature for the User, Group and Membership (or even Directory information that is requested in CWD-1295) so the customer can process the exported CSV into other useful information (eg: Reporting) as well as use it for the *CSV User Import* where the password is actually not a required field.
fields.summary: Provide Crowd ability to export User, Group and Membership information into CSV

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Replicate
 # Configure Crowd with *Azure Active Directory*
 ** [Configuring Azure Active Directory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/configuring-azure-active-directory-935372375.html]
 # Choose *specific groups from Azure AD* and add the groups to the Crowd *Group Filtering*.
 # *Synchronise* the directory.
 # Add Crowd directory in any Atlassian Application (tested with *Confluence*)
 # Allow *only specific group* to authenticate to the application.
 # *Synchronise* the directory.
 # Get one of the user from *Crowd (Azure Directory)* to *Login* into *Confluence*.

h3. Expected Behaviour

Only *specific groups from Azure AD* that is part of the *Group Filtering* added into Confluence and Crowd.
h3. Actual Behaviour

If the user belongs to any other group in Azure AD (*not* part of the groups in *Group Filtering*) additional Group is added into *Confluence and Crowd* after the user *Login* into Confluence (or Crowd integrated application).
 * [^crowdAzure.mp4]

List of Groups in Azure AD
 * !azureGroup.png|thumbnail!

(i) *Synchronising* the *Azure AD directory in Crowd* helps to remove the groups temporarily until the next user login.
h3. Workaround

In order to mitigate the issue admins can disable membership synchronisation during user log in. Adding groups during log in can be disabled. Here are the steps to apply the workaround:
 # Check the directory ID of the Azure AD directory:

{noformat}
select id from cwd_directory where directory_name = 'here put directory name';{noformat}
Please note that directory name is case sensitive. This query will result with ID you need in next step.

      2. Disable membership synchronisation during user log in:
{noformat}
insert into cwd_directory_attribute VALUES (here_put_dir_id, 'crowd.sync.group.membership.after.successful.user.auth.enabled', false);
{noformat}
Where here_put_dir_id is the directory ID from step 1.

The workaround doesn't require restart of Crowd.
h4. Drawbacks of the workaround:
 * Memberships won't be synchronised during user log in anymore. This means that when you add a user to group in Azure AD you'll have to sync the directory in Crowd. Synchronisation needs to be scheduled to run reasonably often.
fields.summary: Crowd Azure AD Group Filtering add non Filter Group after a successful user Login

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

During an active session, you can't change your password if it gets expired
h3. Steps to Reproduce

1) Login Crowd through admin and set expiry day as 1
 2) Changed the local time of machine to 2 min before the expiry time
 3) Login with a user in the crowd
 4) Wait for 2 min to get over and try to change the password.
 5) You will get an invalid password response even if the previous password you entered is correct.
 6) Log and try to login again, I got the message that your password is expired and then you are able to change the password
h3. Expected Results

We should be able to change the password if we are already logged in and the password gets expired
h3. Actual Results
Invalid password

h3. Workaround
 You would need to logout so that you get a password expiry window to change your password
fields.summary: During an active session,you can't change your password if it gets expired

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary


The /status/ endpoint for Crowd will return as healthy (200 OK) even in conditions where Crowd is not in a healthy state, such as having lost connection to the database

h3. Steps to Reproduce

- Using a sample Crowd installation connected to a PostgreSQL database server, we stopped the database server while Crowd was running. 
- This resulted in Crowd constantly logging org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: The connection attempt failed.
- Our attempts to access Crowd webapp resulted in HTTP 500. 
- Requesting /status/ endpoint resulted in HTTP 200 and following response body:

h3. Expected Results

- Connecting to the /status/ endpoint would return an error 500 or return an ERROR state instead of a RUNNING or OK state.

h3. Actual Results

The /status/ endpoint on Crowd will return as OK / RUNNING as if the node was healthy. 

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.

The only thing is /rest/healthcheck/1.0/check endpoint which will return 500 in such case. But the endpoint that is designed to be watched by load balancer is /status/, and that endpoint has no known workaround to get it to respond.
fields.summary: Crowd /status/ endpoint remains as healthy even if database is offline

fields.description:
h3. Problem Description

The following appears in atlassian-crowd.log.
{code:java}
2020-02-19 20:30:15,450 http-nio-8095-exec-42 ERROR [[Catalina].[localhost].[/crowd].[default]] Servlet.service() for servlet [default] in context with path [/crowd] threw exception
java.lang.RuntimeException: net.sf.ehcache.CacheException: java.io.StreamCorruptedException: invalid stream header: 00000000
....
Caused by: net.sf.ehcache.CacheException: java.io.StreamCorruptedException: invalid stream header: 00000000
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.disk.DiskStorageFactory.retrieve(DiskStorageFactory.java:891)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.disk.Segment.decodeHit(Segment.java:182)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.disk.Segment.get(Segment.java:225)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.disk.DiskStore.fault(DiskStore.java:210)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.CacheStore$4.call(CacheStore.java:198)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.CacheStore$4.call(CacheStore.java:192)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.cachingtier.OnHeapCachingTier$Fault.get(OnHeapCachingTier.java:334)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.cachingtier.OnHeapCachingTier$Fault.access$200(OnHeapCachingTier.java:311)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.cachingtier.OnHeapCachingTier.get(OnHeapCachingTier.java:175)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.CacheStore.get(CacheStore.java:192)
	at net.sf.ehcache.Cache.get(Cache.java:1734)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.cache.EhcacheBackedCache.get(EhcacheBackedCache.java:42)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.dao.token.TokenDAOMemory.findByIdentifierHash(TokenDAOMemory.java:89)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.token.SwitchableTokenManagerImpl.findByIdentifierHash(SwitchableTokenManagerImpl.java:123)
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor610.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
....
Caused by: java.io.StreamCorruptedException: invalid stream header: 00000000
	at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readStreamHeader(ObjectInputStream.java:866)
	at java.io.ObjectInputStream.<init>(ObjectInputStream.java:358)
	at net.sf.ehcache.util.PreferredLoaderObjectInputStream.<init>(PreferredLoaderObjectInputStream.java:40)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.disk.DiskStorageFactory.read(DiskStorageFactory.java:368)
	at net.sf.ehcache.store.disk.DiskStorageFactory.retrieve(DiskStorageFactory.java:864)
....{code}
h3. Cause

The files used by ehcache to optimize the requests to the database have become corrupted on disk and cannot be used by the Crowd. 

The underlying reason for the corruption is unknown and under investigation at this time. 
h3. Workaround

The files in the cache need to be deleted form the temporary directory. First check where the temp files are located, this is identified by the Java system parameter java.io.tmpdir. To find this in Linux run this command from the installation directory

CROWD ...
{code:java}
sudo jinfo `cat apache-tomcat/work/catalina.pid` | fgrep "java.io.tmpdir ="
{code}
In general the location will usually be one of
 * /tmp
 * <crowd-install>/apache-tomcat/temp/

Then
 # Shutdown Crowd
 # Delete the files in the directory identified by the jinfo command for java.io.tmpdir
 # Restart Crowd
fields.summary: Crowd fails with net.sf.ehcache.CacheException: java.io.StreamCorruptedException: invalid stream header

h3. Summary
Currently, Crowd will fill SAML response XML with original username, not an alias. Unfortunately, this is a global change and will affect all applications connected to Crowd. This caused admin having some limitation on integrating Crowd with other application.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When connecting Crowd to an external user directory such as LDAP it keeps track of users that have been deleted from LDAP but have relating content in our applications- these are known as inactive users. An example database entry will resemble the following in the cwd_user table:
||user_name||lower_user_name||active||created||updated||first||lower_first||last||lower_last||display||lower_display||email||lower_email||cred||deleted_externally||external_id||
|OrosA|orosa|0|2020-01-21 16:24:28|2020-01-23 16:37:37|Amina|amina|Oros|oros|Amina Oros [X]|amina oros|OrosA@test.mydomain.com|orosa@test.mydomain.com|nopass|1|d09a10df73ffd7498f3053a324a8083d|

It appears when users to be deleted are calculated, then *all users(active + inactive) from database are taken into account, but only active should be.*
{code:java}
class UsnChangedCacheRefresher
method validateAndReturnGuidsToAddAndDelete(DirectoryCache directoryCache)

bug:
final Set<String> guidsInCache = ImmutableSet.copyOf(directoryCache.getAllUserGuids());
{code}
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Connect an Atlassian application to external user directory
 # Create content for a user
 # Remove this user from the external user directory

h3. Expected Results

Crowd will mark this user as inactive and never reference this user again while syncing with external user directories
h3. Actual Results

Crowd continues using the inactive / externally deleted user when calculating users it needs to delete. As this behavior accumulates in larger environments it will lead to longer synchronization times

The sync logs from atlassian-jira.log for example will resemble the following:
{noformat}
2020-01-23 16:37:37,499 Caesium-1-2 INFO ServiceRunner     [c.a.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] deleted [ 1 ] users in [ 21ms ]
2020-01-23 16:41:08,432 Caesium-1-4 INFO ServiceRunner     [c.a.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] deleted [ 1 ] users in [ 10ms ]
2020-01-23 16:41:21,206 Caesium-1-2 INFO ServiceRunner     [c.a.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] deleted [ 1 ] users in [ 11ms ]
{noformat}

Notice how Crowd is attempting to "delete" the same user ( depicted above ) over and over again 

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: When syncing with external directories Crowd is mistakenly including inactive users that have been deleted externally

fields.description:
Novell eDirectory uses the {{loginDisabled: FALSE}} or loginDisabled: FALSE to mark users as inactive or active.

The value of this attribute is not reflected in Crowd. A Crowd user is always active in an LDAP Connector directory unless the user is manually disabled in Crowd.

Please add support for this attribute. Or even better make the active flag customizable in Crowd based any LDAP attribute.

*Steps to reproduce*
 # Create and configure LDAP Connector Directory in Crowd of type Novell eDirectory
 # Sync the users
 # Mark a user as {{loginDisabled: FALSE}} in LDAP
 # Sync the users

*Expected behavior*

**User is marked as inactive in Crowd

*Actual* *behavior*

The user is still marked as active in Crowd
fields.summary: Support sync for active/inactive status with Novell eDirectory

fields.description:
The  OpenID client application in Atlassian Crowd before version 3.6.2, and from version 3.7.0 before 3.7.1 allows remote attackers to perform a Denial of Service attack via an XML Entity Expansion vulnerability. This issue was addressed by disabling the OpenID client application in Crowd. 

Please be aware that the OpenID client application is a testing app used as a starting point for developing OpenID-enabled Java applications. It is bundled with the standard Crowd distribution and it was deployed by default prior to Crowd Version 3.6.2. Moreover it runs in the same Tomcat container as the Crowd and OpenID Server. However, this application is not required for Crowd or OpenID server to work correctly. Regarding this security vulnerability, the OpenID client application has been disabled by default since Crowd version 3.6.2. If you are running older version of Crowd, and at the moment you are unable to update Crowd, then you can disable the  Crowd OpenID client application manually by executing the procedure found [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/disabling-the-openid-client-app-986879764.html].
fields.summary: XXE in OpenID client application - CVE-2019-20104

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When admins use the Atlassian Importer feature to import users and groups from Jira to a internal user directory in Crowd, the users and groups get imported however, but their memberships do not. This case is seen when the ***Use nested groups* option in the internal directory configuration is set. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In Jira create nested groups and assign users to these groups. 
 # In Crowd configure an internal directory and set the *use nested groups* option. 
 # In Crowd head over to *Users > Import Users > Atlassian Importer*
 # Configure the import options and assign the users/groups to the internal directory.
 # Import

h3. Expected Results

All the users, and groups with all their memberships are imported. 
h3. Actual Results

Users and groups are imported but their memberships are not. group-user and group-group memberships are not imported. 
h3. Workaround

No workaround at the moment
fields.summary: Importing Users from JIRA using the Atlassian Importer to a Internal Directory in Crowd does not import nested groups and user memberships

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When admins use the Atlassian Importer feature to import users and groups from Jira to a delegated user directory in Crowd, the users and groups get imported however, only the group-user memberships are imported. Group-group memberships are not imported. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In Jira create nested groups and assign users to these groups. 
 # In Crowd configure a delegated directory and set the *Use nested groups* option
 # In Crowd head over to *Users > Import Users > Atlassian Importer*
 # Configure the import options and assign the users/groups to the delegated directory.
 # Import

h3. Expected Results

All the users, and groups with all their memberships are imported. 
h3. Actual Results

Users and groups are imported but only the group-user memberships are imported. Group-group memberships are not.
h3. Workaround

No workaround at the moment
fields.summary: Importing Users from JIRA using the Atlassian Importer to a Delegated Directory in Crowd does not import nested groups

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

During user directory sync between Crowd 3.7.0 and Jira, where both were running with MySQL database, queries triggered by the directory FULL Sync against table *cwd_membership* were doing full scan. This table has around 3.5 million rows for the affected customer.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Perform FULL synchronisation for directory:
Caesium-2-1 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] FULL synchronisation for directory [ 66650113 ] starting
# It fails to complete:
Caesium-2-1 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] failed synchronisation complete for directory [ 66650113 ] in [ 9503296ms ]

h3. Expected Results

The FULL sync completes successfully.

h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-crowd.log file:
{noformat}
2019-10-31 13:56:40,550 Caesium-2-4 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] FULL synchronisation for directory [ 66650113 ] starting
First time ERROR's seen
2019-10-31 15:25:25,457 Caesium-2-4 ERROR [hibernate.batch.hibernate5.Hibernate5BatchProcessor] Could not process class com.atlassian.crowd.util.persistence.hibernate.batch.TransactionGroup: com.a
tlassian.crowd.util.persistence.hibernate.batch.TransactionGroup@126b66d3[primaryObject=com.atlassian.crowd.model.group.InternalGroup@7ddc47a8[id=69033307,name=DL-EXAMPLE-1,ty
pe=GROUP,active=true,description=*** Deleted Mail DL 12/19/2018 per TASK1666016 by P2184675adm ***,lowerName=dl-example-1,createdDate=2019-10-04 23:11:05.0,updatedDate=2019-10
-04 23:11:05.0,directoryId=66650113,externalId=b147b4b93a0bde4289a6b4f951f3baf3]]
2019-10-31 15:25:39,290 Caesium-2-4 ERROR [hibernate.batch.hibernate5.Hibernate5BatchProcessor] Could not process class com.atlassian.crowd.util.persistence.hibernate.batch.TransactionGroup: com.a
tlassian.crowd.util.persistence.hibernate.batch.TransactionGroup@93b6be5[primaryObject=com.atlassian.crowd.model.group.InternalGroup@6864899a[id=69013590,name=DL-EXAMPLE-2
,type=GROUP,active=true,description=*** Deleted Mail DL 09/04/2018 per TASK1413175 by p2187871ADM ***,lowerName=dl-example-2,createdDate=2019-10-04 23:11:05.0,updatedDate=
2019-10-04 23:11:05.0,directoryId=66650113,externalId=a1eed53126adda4cbe63b61c0580411e]]
2019-10-31 16:39:14,030 Caesium-2-4 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] failed synchronisation complete for directory [ 66650113 ] in [ 9753486ms ]
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
* Query 1 doing full table scan in Jira MySQL Database. 
{noformat}
explain select * FROM jiradb.cwd_membership WHERE membership_type='GROUP_USER' AND child_name='P2895647' AND directory_id=10600 ;
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
id	select_type	table	type	possible_keys	key	key_len	ref	rows	Extra
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
1	SIMPLE	cwd_membership	ALL	NULL	NULL	NULL	NULL	14310854	Using where
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
{noformat}
* Adding the index below fix this.
{noformat}
CREATE INDEX idx_upperchild_mem_dir USING BTREE ON jiradb.cwd_membership (child_name,membership_type,directory_id);
{noformat}

* Query 2 also doing full table scans. 
{noformat}
mysql> explain select * FROM jiradb.cwd_membership WHERE parent_name='dl-example' AND directory_id=10600;
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
id	select_type	table	type	possible_keys	key	key_len	ref	rows	Extra
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
1	SIMPLE	cwd_membership	ALL	NULL	NULL	NULL	NULL	14387270	Using where
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
{noformat}
* Adding the second index below fix this.
{noformat}
CREATE INDEX idx_upperparent_dir USING BTREE ON jiradb.cwd_membership (parent_name,directory_id);
{noformat}

*Please note*: This issue can also happen with the Embedded Crowd for Jira. The above workaround is also valid for this case.
fields.summary: Creating indexes for Jira table cwd_membership during User Directory Sync with Crowd 3.7.0

fields.description:
h2. Please be aware that Atlassian does not consider this issue to represent a security risk as the functionality is restricted to users with administrative rights.

h3. Issue Summary

When adding a Jira server in Bamboo under the "User directories" module, an attacker can put any value in the "Server URL" field and the response from the server is returned to the client. Yes, it's true that if an attacker already had admin on a Bamboo instance, they can do a whole lot more damaging things, but this effectively allows them to scan the internal network that the Bamboo instance is sitting on and determine what other endpoints they can exploit. This vulnerability is especially useful if an attacker does not have a shell on the host and has just popped the Bamboo we app.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Login to Admin user
 # Navigate to Bamboo administration (11.png)
 # Click on User directories (22.png)
 # Click on Add Directory (33.png)
 # Select Directory type to JIRA (44.png)
 # Enter Server URL as [http://127.0.0.1:8000|http://127.0.0.1:8000/] (55.png)
 # Click on test settings (66.png)
 # Observe the request to server (77.png)
 # Message for open port 80 (88.png)
 # Message for non http open port (92.png)
 # Message for Closed port (94.png)
fields.summary: SSRF when adding Jira server in admin plugin

fields.description:
Most Atlassian Products have been updated to add support for the current Long-Term-Support version of Java (11) and OpenJDK, as mentioned in our Community post here:
 * [Java 11 / OpenJDK support update for Server and Da... - Atlassian Community|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Agile-articles/Java-11-OpenJDK-support-update-for-Server-and-Data-Center/ba-p/967836]

In the post, Crowd 4.0+ is referenced as supporting the above, with it having a 2019 release, which never came.

This is a concern for some customers, as the latest version of Crowd, 3.7, only supports Java 8, which will reach end of life status at the end of this year.

The suggestion is to add support for Java 11/OpenJDK in the next version of Crowd.
fields.summary: Add Crowd Support for Java Release 11

fields.description:
h3. Information

Crowd can [specify which group can access an Application|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/specifying-which-groups-can-access-an-application-25788430.html] from the UI. However, the UI method will require more time when the list of groups to add in grow longer. 

We can make use of the REST API method to speed this up:
* [Crowd REST API Reference - Update application directory mapping|https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-crowd/3.5.1/REST/#admin/1.0/application-updateApplicationDirectoryMapping]

h3. Problem Definition
Using the REST API above to update the {{*allowGroups*}} list can easily include a long list of groups but there is no *validity* for group names that are entered.

For Example, in there REST API admin can add in the group name that doesn't already exist in Crowd and the REST call will be updated successfully. The non-existed group name will be displayed in the UI as well. This can cause confusion to the Crowd admin when they are back to review the groups that are allowed to access an application.

h3. Tested Environment
Crowd 3.5.1

h3. Suggested Solution
Add in a validate step for each group names to be updated
fields.summary: REST API for Update application directory mapping does not validate Group Name

fields.description:
Crowd SSO 2.0 requires that mapping of user directories in Crowd and the connected applications to be identical.

[Crowd SSO 2.0|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-sso-2-0-967322291.html]
{quote}Only users existing in Crowd user directory can use SSO 2.0. Make sure that users from your application's individual user directories also exist in Crowd user directory. To avoid any potential conflicts, mapping of user directories on the application side and Crowd must be identical.
{quote}
The above constraint poses issues with SSO 2.0 implementation when it is not possible to create identical group structure between different applications.
fields.summary: Allow Crowd SSO 2.0 to work without constraining it to only applications having the same user directory mapping

fields.description:
h3. Suggestion Summary

Update documentation to add information about how to regenerate Crowd Certificate for SSO 2.0

In the [Crowd SSO 2.0 Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-sso-2-0-967322291.html] there is a mention about regenrating the certificate in the case of security breach and here is the quote from the documentation:
{quote}
Crowd's certificate is by default valid for 5 years. After that time, you'll have to regenerate the certificate and manually copy it over to individual applications for which you want to use SSO 2.0. In case of a security breach, for safety reasons we suggest that you regenerate the certificate and copy it to your applications immediately.

Remember that a regenerated certificate needs to be again provided in all application you want to use SSO with.
{quote}

However there isn't any step documented about how to regenerate the cert.

h3. Environment
 * Crowd 3.4 onwards (that supports SSO 2.0)


h3. Suggestion
Include the method to regenerate the certificate for Crowd into the official documentation

h3. Resolution
Follow the REST API call that is mentioned in the REST API page below:
* https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-crowd/3.7.0/REST/#admin/1.0//samlconfig-resetSamlConfiguration

{code}
POST /rest/admin/1.0//samlconfig/reset-certificates
{code}
fields.summary: Update documentation to add information about how to regenerate Crowd Certificate for SSO 2.0

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 10 September 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

 We have released a new version of [Delegated Directory Pruning plugin for Crowd (1.1.0)|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1218630/delegated-directory-pruning-for-crowd?hosting=server&tab=versions] which contains fix for this issue. Please upgrade your Delegated Directory Pruning plugin for Crowd to aforementioned version.

Best regards,
Crowd team
{panel}
  
h3. Issue Summary

When the connector type is set to DELEGATED, we can opt for pruning plugin to disable users who are disabled in AD. However, the scheduled pruning job doesn't seem to run if the user's entry for externalID is NULL in DB
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Download the [Delegated Directory Pruning for Crowd Plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1218630/delegated-directory-pruning-for-crowd?hosting=server&tab=overview].
 # Stop Crowd
 # Place the jar downloaded from the above link inside the <crowd-home/plugin> folder
 # Restart Crowd
 # Once restarted login to the Crowd UI
 # Access the directory in question on the left-hand panel, you would see *Configure Pruning*

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

"Unique constraint violation" error while switching applink in the Crowd-connected application. Following error is seen when SQL logging is enabled:
{code:java|title=Error seen with SQL debug logging}
2019-11-25 18:01:56,195 http-nio-8095-exec-14 DEBUG [org.hibernate.SQL] insert into cwd_application_attribute (application_id, attribute_name, attribute_value) values (?, ?, ?)
2019-11-25 18:01:56,195 http-nio-8095-exec-14 TRACE [type.descriptor.sql.BasicBinder] binding parameter [1] as [BIGINT] - [37879809]
2019-11-25 18:01:56,195 http-nio-8095-exec-14 TRACE [type.descriptor.sql.BasicBinder] binding parameter [2] as [VARCHAR] - [applicationLinkId]
2019-11-25 18:01:56,195 http-nio-8095-exec-14 TRACE [type.descriptor.sql.BasicBinder] binding parameter [3] as [VARCHAR] - [3c66e104-82c6-3ad3-a663-2b055e5fe0a0]
2019-11-25 18:01:56,203 http-nio-8095-exec-14 ERROR [jdbc.batch.internal.BatchingBatch] HHH000315: Exception executing batch [java.sql.BatchUpdateException: ORA-00001: unique constraint (AWS_CROWD.SYS_C005244) violated
], SQL: insert into cwd_application_attribute (application_id, attribute_name, attribute_value) values (?, ?, ?)
{code}
We can see from the database, that the {{attribute_value}} attribute in the {{cwd_application_attribute}} is _null_.
{code:sql|title=SELECT * FROM cwd_application_attribute WHERE application_id = '37879809' and attribute_name = 'applicationLinkId';}
(37879809,null,'applicationLinkId');
{code}
The issue is limited to only the Oracle database.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Chose a Crowd-connected application.
 # Select the relevant applink for the application for Crowd to communicate with the application.
 # Save the settings
 # Edit the application again and change the applink to deselect the earlier chosen applink. eg: From Bitbuket to _select application link -_ save is successful.
 # Hit Save, save is successful.- Notice the error
 # Try to select the Application Link again: Hit Save - Notice the error

h3. Expected Results

We should be able to deselect the applink without any issues.
h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown
{code:java}
2019-11-28 15:07:20,477 http-nio-8095-exec-13 ERROR [jdbc.batch.internal.BatchingBatch] HHH000315: Exception executing batch [java.sql.BatchUpdateException: ORA-00001: unique constraint (AWS_CROWD.SYS_C005244) violated
], SQL: insert into cwd_application_attribute (application_id, attribute_name, attribute_value) values (?, ?, ?)
2019-11-28 15:07:20,479 http-nio-8095-exec-13 WARN [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] SQL Error: 1, SQLState: 23000
2019-11-28 15:07:20,479 http-nio-8095-exec-13 ERROR [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] ORA-00001: unique constraint (AWS_CROWD.SYS_C005244) violated

2019-11-28 15:07:20,479 http-nio-8095-exec-13 WARN [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] SQL Error: 1, SQLState: 23000
2019-11-28 15:07:20,479 http-nio-8095-exec-13 ERROR [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] ORA-00001: unique constraint (AWS_CROWD.SYS_C005244) violated

2019-11-28 15:07:20,484 http-nio-8095-exec-13 ERROR [org.hibernate.internal.ExceptionMapperStandardImpl] HHH000346: Error during managed flush [org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not execute batch]
2019-11-28 15:07:20,488 http-nio-8095-exec-13 ERROR [crowd.xwork.interceptors.TransactionalInvocation] Action /console/secure/application/update.action (UpdateApplication.execute()) is already completed and can not be committed again.
2019-11-28 15:07:20,955 http-nio-8095-exec-13 ERROR [500ErrorPage] Exception caught in 500 page could not execute batch; SQL [insert into cwd_application_attribute (application_id, attribute_name, attribute_value) values (?, ?, ?)]; constraint [AWS_CROWD.SYS_C005244]; nested exception is org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not execute batch
org.springframework.dao.DataIntegrityViolationException: could not execute batch; SQL [insert into cwd_application_attribute (application_id, attribute_name, attribute_value) values (?, ?, ?)]; constraint [AWS_CROWD.SYS_C005244]; nested exception is org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not execute batch
        at org.springframework.orm.hibernate5.SessionFactoryUtils.convertHibernateAccessException(SessionFactoryUtils.java:241)
        at org.springframework.orm.hibernate5.HibernateTransactionManager.convertHibernateAccessException(HibernateTransactionManager.java:755)
        at org.springframework.orm.hibernate5.HibernateTransactionManager.doCommit(HibernateTransactionManager.java:594)
        at org.springframework.transaction.support.AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.processCommit(AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.java:765)
        at org.springframework.transaction.support.AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.commit(AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.java:734)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.xwork.interceptors.TransactionalInvocation.commitOrRollbackTransaction(TransactionalInvocation.java:80)
{code}
h3. Workaround

There are 2 possible workarounds for now:
 # Once the applink is chosen for the application, do not change it to {{select application link}} to deselect the applink.
 # You can also use the following SQL query to manually add the applink to the application:
{code:sql}
UPDATE cwd_application_attribute
SET attribute_value = '<application-link-ID>'
WHERE application_id = '<application-ID>' and attribute_name = 'applicationLinkId';
{code}
The {{application-link-ID}} is of the application link which you are trying to choose for the application. The {{application-ID}} is of the Crowd-connected application.
 *Example query:*
{code:sql}
UPDATE cwd_application_attribute
SET attribute_value = '3c66e104-82c6-3ad3-a663-2b055e5fe0a0'
WHERE application_id = '37879809' and attribute_name = 'applicationLinkId';
{code}

h4. Extras

A screenshot of the exception thrown from a test in another similar setup:

!Screenshot 2019-11-28 at 7.18.37 PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: "Unique constraint violation" error while switching applink in the Crowd-connected application

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Synchronising an external user directory (connector, such as LDAP) fails completely during the group membership step, if there are usernames of format {{uniqueMember: username}} in the group.  
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Connect a user directory (LDAP) in Bitbucket Server
 # An LDIF of a group (that will fail) looks like (Note uniqueMember:johndoe)
{noformat}
group1, group, doman
dn: cn=group1,ou=groups,dc=xxx,dc=xx
uniqueMember: johndoe
uniqueMember: uid=janedoe,ou=people,dc=xxx,dc=xxxx
.......
objectClass: top
objectClass: groupOfUniqueNames
cn: group1
{noformat}

 # Click Synchronize

h3. Expected Results
 * Synchronization to be proceed, skipping invalid users names
 * Group membership synchronization for that group to be skipped
 * Sync process to continue synch'ing other groups

h3. Actual Results

The directory fails to synchronise.

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bitbucket.log file with debug enabled on Crowd class: {{com.atlassian.crowd}}. The group with the malformed names is the last listed before the error.
{noformat}
 DEBUG [Caesium-1-1]  c.a.c.d.l.monitoring.TimedSupplier Timed call for lookup with mapper on cn=group1,ou=groups,dc=xxxx,dc=xx took 3ms
 INFO  [Caesium-1-1]  c.a.c.d.DbCachingRemoteDirectory failed synchronisation complete for directory [ x ] in [ x ms ]
 DEBUG [Caesium-1-1]  c.a.s.i.crowd.HibernateDirectoryDao Updating object: com.atlassian.crowd.model.directory.DirectoryImpl@6b8e0580[lowerName=ldap server,description=<null>,type=CONNECTOR,implementationClass=com.atlassian.crowd.directory.OpenLDAP,allowedOperations=[DELETE_GROUP, CREATE_GROUP, UPDATE_GROUP, UPDATE_GROUP_ATTRIBUTE, UPDATE_USER_ATTRIBUTE],attributes={ldap.basedn=DC=xxx,DC=xx, ldap.user.filter=(&(objectClass=posixAccount)), ldap.user.username=uid, ldap.usermembership.use=false, com.atlassian.crowd.directory.sync.lastdurationms=22784, autoAddGroups=stash-users, crowd.sync.incremental.enabled=true, ldap.group.usernames=uniqueMember, ldap.pagedresults.size=1000, ldap.read.timeout=120000, crowd.sync.group.membership.after.successful.user.auth.enabled=only_when_first_created, ldap.connection.timeout=10000, ldap.group.filter=(&(objectclass=groupOfUniqueNames)), ldap.roles.disabled=true, ldap.external.id=uid, ldap.url=xxxxx, ldap.usermembership.use.for.groups=false, ldap.pagedresults=false, ldap.user.password=userPassword, ldap.user.lastname=sn, ldap.group.name=cn, ldap.user.objectclass=posixAccount, directory.cache.synchronise.interval=3600, ldap.nestedgroups.disabled=false, ldap.secure=true, ldap.referral=false, ldap.user.username.rdn=cn, com.atlassian.crowd.directory.sync.issynchronising=false, ldap.propogate.changes=false, ldap.group.dn=ou=groups, ldap.pool.timeout=0, ldap.user.displayname=uid, ldap.relaxed.dn.standardisation=true, ldap.user.firstname=givenName, com.atlassian.crowd.directory.sync.laststartsynctime=1574246377919, ldap.user.email=mail, ldap.user.group=uid, localUserStatusEnabled=false, ldap.user.encryption=sha, ldap.local.groups=true, ldap.group.description=description, ldap.user.dn=OU=People, ldap.group.objectclass=groupOfUniqueNames, ldap.filter.expiredUsers=false, ldap.search.timelimit=60000}]
2019-11-20 11:40:00,713 ERROR [Caesium-1-1]  c.a.c.d.DbCachingDirectoryPoller Error occurred while refreshing the cache for directory [ x ].
java.lang.RuntimeException: javax.naming.InvalidNameException: Invalid name: johndoe
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC4519Directory$3.apply(RFC4519Directory.java:837)
...
Caused by: javax.naming.InvalidNameException: Invalid name: johndoe
	at javax.naming.ldap.Rfc2253Parser.doParse(Rfc2253Parser.java:111)
	at javax.naming.ldap.Rfc2253Parser.parseDn(Rfc2253Parser.java:70)
	at javax.naming.ldap.LdapName.parse(LdapName.java:785)
	at javax.naming.ldap.LdapName.<init>(LdapName.java:123)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC4519Directory$3.apply(RFC4519Directory.java:835)
	... 38 common frames omitted
{noformat}
h3. Workaround
 # Remove the users with the misformatted names ({{jdoe}}, {{instead of uid=jdoe,ou=people,o=domain}}) in LDAP
 # Try to sync again.
 Check if it fails again:
{code:java}
ERROR [Caesium-1-1] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingDirectoryPoller] pollChanges Error occurred while refreshing the cache for directory [ 111111 ].
{code}
And if another group is listed right before that error:
{code:java}
[crowd.directory.ldap.SpringLdapTemplateWrapper] call Timed call for lookup with mapper on cn=group2,ou=groups,o=domain took 34ms
{code}
Then fix it the same way on the LDAP server (removing the malformatted usernames)

You can check all the groups with malformatted usernames more quickly by excluding each group in the group user filter with (!(cn=group1))

fields.description:
h3. Description

+As a+ System Admin of a Crowd instance with a very high number of users and changes per day
 +I want+ to be able to filter Audit Log searches by username, no matter which directory they are listed in
 +So that+ I can see audit log events related to that user selecting only one entry, improving UX

Currently the user filter shows one entry for each audit log entity object, which would map to any single match for that user name in any directory, even inactive or previously removed ones.
 Also it doesn't show to which directory each entry displayed is related.

!Screen Shot 2019-11-20 at 10.53.11.png|thumbnail!
h3. Proposed Solution

Filter could allow selection for +per directory+ or +per user+
h3. Possible Workarounds

Select all user name matches displayed to filter by that user
fields.summary: Remove duplicate user names in Audit Log Filters

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Crowd administration panel can take longer to respond if the marketplace is unreachable.

h3. Environment

* Crowd 3.7
* UPM 3.0.7

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Add entry in */etc/hosts* to simulate marketplace being unreachable:
{code}
203.56.8.1 marketplace.atlassian.com
{code}
# Try to visit the Manage Apps page, notice it is trying to reach the marketplace
# Try to click on other items of the admin panel before the request to the marketplace times out

h3. Expected Results

Pages load quickly.

h3. Actual Results

If the thread is still trying to reach the marketplace, the menus will not load until the request times out:
{code}
2019-11-20 11:40:52,854 http-nio-8095-exec-17 INFO [atlassian.marketplace.client.MarketplaceClient] GET https://marketplace.atlassian.com/rest/2/
2019-11-20 11:41:07,856 http-nio-8095-exec-17 WARN [atlassian.upm.pac.PacClientImpl] Error when querying application info from MPAC: com.atlassian.marketplace.client.MpacException: org.apache.http.conn.ConnectTimeoutException: Connect to marketplace.atlassian.com:443 [marketplace.atlassian.com/203.56.8.1] failed: connect timed out
{code}

The browser tab will hang if you click on any other item in Crowd in the time frame between the messages above (marketplace request and timeout).

h3. Notes

This bug is similar to the following one which affects Confluence:

* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-58927

h3. Workaround

In Crowd, disable connectivity to Marketplace:

* Cog Icon >> General Configuration >> Manage Apps >> Settings >> Uncheck the 'Connect to the Atlassian Marketplace' box, then click 'Apply'

Or, configure an outbound proxy as the Internet gateway for Crowd so the Marketplace address can be reached:

* [How to Configure Outbound HTTP and HTTPS Proxy for your Atlassian application|https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/how-to-configure-outbound-http-and-https-proxy-for-your-atlassian-application-834000120.html]
fields.summary: If the Marketplace is unreachable, UPM causes Crowd to hang

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Crowd has the option to import users from Bamboo, Confluence and Jira natively using the *Import Users* feature that is described in the documentation below:
* [Import Bamboo User to Crowd|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/importing-users-from-atlassian-bamboo-105185573.html]
* [Import Confluence User to Crowd|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/importing-users-from-atlassian-confluence-30736434.html]
* [Import Jira User to Crowd|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/importing-users-from-atlassian-jira-30736459.html]

However, there isn't an option for Bitbucket.

h3. Suggested Solution
Implementing the same user import option for Bitbucket

h3. Possible Workaround
Export the users into CSV file and import it using the CSV option in Crowd:
* [Importing Users from CSV Files|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/importing-users-from-csv-files-64454760.html]
fields.summary: Crowd to have native user import option from Bitbucket

fields.description:
h3. Suggestion Summary

Create documentation or add information to [Crowd with MySQL page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/mysql-4030924.html] that clarifies the usage of parameter *rewriteBatchedStatements* found in Crowd JDBC string after configuration with MySQL database.

h3. Environment
 * Crowd 3.2 onwards
 * [Supported version of MySQL DB|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/supported-platforms-191851.html]

h3. Steps to Reproduce:
 # After configuring Crowd (version 3.2 onwards) with MySQL, edit file crowd.cfg.xml
 # Go to property <property name="hibernate.connection.url">jdbc:mysql:example_database?rewriteBatchedStatements=true</property>
 # *rewriteBatchedStatements=true* will be set

h3. Expected Results

We should have a documentation that allows us to explain customers about parameters from the application.

h3. Actual Results

We can't find Atlassian documentation that explains parameter *rewriteBatchedStatements*.

h3. Notes from Crowd DoS

{{rewriteBatchedStatements=true}} is available since Crowd 3.2 when development did some performance improvements with regard to Crowd database connectivity, and added this parameter as part of the improvements. Crowd will automatically add this parameter if it detects MySQL Database, and similar parameters are in place for other database engines as well.

This is purely meant to improve the performance of Crowd's syncs.

If you would like Crowd to not add this parameter by default then, you should supply the parameter by yourself with *false* value in the DB connection URL.
fields.summary: Crowd - Documentation for rewriteBatchedStatements parameter

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

It is not possible to disable those features through the following system properties on Crowd:

{code}
-Datlassian.upm.server.data.disable=true -Dupm.pac.disable=true
{code}

They are documented here:

* [Disabling analytics information sharing|https://confluence.atlassian.com/upm/configuring-marketplace-connectivity-306350947.html]
* [Problems Connecting to the Atlassian Marketplace|https://confluence.atlassian.com/upm/problems-connecting-to-the-atlassian-marketplace-273875718.html]

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Edit *<Crowd-Install>/apache-tomcat/bin/setenv.sh*
# Add the following system properties:
{code}
-Datlassian.upm.server.data.disable=true -Dupm.pac.disable=true
{code}
# Start Crowd

h3. Expected Results

Marketplace connection and analytics are disabled after startup.

h3. Actual Results

Both features remain enabled.

h3. Workaround

Disable those features through the UI after startup:

fields.description:
Comparing the with the old version of Crowd, the following new plugins added to the Crowd caused some slowness on the Crowd UI response time due to the lack of caching mechanism.  

The following query has been executed 11 times which cause 120 ms extra on the UI response time:
{code}
select this_.id as id1_26_0_, this_.parent_id as parent_i2_26_0_, this_.child_id as child_id3_26_0_, this_.membership_type as membersh4_26_0_, this_.group_type as group_ty5_26_0_, this_.parent_name as parent_n6_26_0_, this_.lower_parent_name as lower_pa7_26_0_, this_.child_name as child_na8_26_0_, this_.lower_child_name as lower_ch9_26_0_, this_.created_date as created10_26_0_, this_.directory_id as directo11_26_0_ from cwd_membership this_ where this_.directory_id=? and this_.lower_parent_name=? and this_.
{code}
Which is coming from the following plugins:
* For cookie token validation (1 times)
* By Crowd NPS Plugin (3 times)
* Crowd analytics Plugin (1 times)
* Application Links Plugin (2 times)

It will be great to cache the result as it is having an impact on all pages.
fields.summary: Cache implementation to improve the UI response time

fields.description: As mentioned in the ticket CWD-5085, We do not recommend using the JDBC driver from Microsoft when connecting with the MSSQL database server. On the other hand, at this point, according to the reproduction test, the Microsoft JDBC is causing slowness on the instance that the response time is double.
fields.summary: Official support for the Microsoft JDBC

fields.description:
We discovered that if you import a CSV into a User Directory, there is no logic to propagate the {{is_local}} column for the group record in {{cwd_group}} table. The fallback behavior will set this value to False, which means that if you import to a User Directory that has remotely managed groups (say, from an LDAP or AD source), on the next sync it will blow away the imported group and configuration.

h2. Example use case

h3. Imported group "Foo" from CSV to an LDAP Connector type User Directory with Local Group Management

!image-2019-11-06-11-23-35-414.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Manually created group in UI for an LDAP Connector type User Directory with Local Group Management

!image-2019-11-06-11-24-02-098.png|thumbnail! 

h2. Workaround?

Because this is a gap in the product design (in that it does not set the {{is_local}} property, you can forcibly set this in the database by updating the imported group to have that value set to True. Don't do this if you don't know why you want to, but here's an example.

(!) Take a backup of your database first and test this in a non-production environment!

{code:sql}
# update all groups in <DIR_ID> (fill this out) to have the is_local value set to True regardless of what it was before
# this will cause all groups in this User Directory to be locally managed
update cwd_group set is_local = 'T' where directory_id = <DIR_ID> and lower_group_name IN ()
{code}
